sub_topic: Finding the magnitude and direction of a vector using trigonometry.
message_1: A force of 20 N is applied at an angle of 30 degrees above the horizontal. What is the magnitude and direction of the resulting vector?
message_2:
To find the magnitude and direction of the resulting vector, we need to break the force vector into its horizontal (x) and vertical (y) components. We can use trigonometry to do this.

The horizontal component (Fx) can be found using the cosine function:
Fx = F * cos(θ)
Fx = 20 N * cos(30°)
Fx ≈ 20 N * 0.866
Fx ≈ 17.32 N

The vertical component (Fy) can be found using the sine function:
Fy = F * sin(θ)
Fy = 20 N * sin(30°)
Fy ≈ 20 N * 0.5
Fy ≈ 10 N

Now that we have the horizontal and vertical components, we can find the magnitude of the resulting vector using the Pythagorean theorem:
R = √(Fx^2 + Fy^2)
R = √((17.32 N)^2 + (10 N)^2)
R = √(299.9424 N^2 + 100 N^2)
R ≈ √(399.9424 N^2)
R ≈ 20 N

The magnitude of the resulting vector is 20 N.

To find the direction of the resulting vector, we can use the arctangent function:
tan(θ) = Fy / Fx
θ = arctan(Fy / Fx)
θ = arctan(10 N / 17.32 N)
θ ≈ 30°

The direction of the resulting vector is 30° above the horizontal.

So, the magnitude and direction of the resulting vector are 20 N and 30° above the horizontal, respectively.
